This report was prepared by S. Widowati, S.W. Handayani, and D. Utami.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  At the request of the Government of Bhutan, the Fact-Finding Mission from the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) visited Bhutan from 25 March to 2 April 2003, to formulate technical 
assistance (TA) for preparing the Road Network Expansion Project.1 ADB held discussions with 
responsible officials of the concerned agencies, including the Ministry of Finance, Department of 
Aid and Debt Management, Ministry of Communications (MOC), Department of Roads (DOR) of 
MOC, Policy and Planning Division (PPD) of MOC, Planning Commission, and the National 
Environmental Commission. This TA was developed on the basis of understanding reached 
during the Mission.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Bhutan, one of the least populated countries in the world, has a population of less than 
700,000 people. About 79% of the population live in rural areas, most of which are concentrated 
in the valleys. The transportation system depends heavily on the road network. Because of the 
mountainous terrain, the area of land suitable for agriculture is very limited and the population is 
distributed  in  remote  scattered  settlements.  The  situation  makes  the  construction  and 
maintenance of roads extremely difficult and costly. 
 
3.  Bhutan has about 3,920 kilometers (km) of roads, comprising about 1,560 km of national 
highways (NHs), 480 km of district roads (DRs), 1,220 km of feeder roads (FRs), and urban and 
forest roads. All NHs and nearly half of the DRs and FRs are paved; however, 20% of NHs, 
53% of DRs, and 86% of FRs are in poor condition. Roads with narrow carriageway widths were 
built along steep hillsides prone to landslides. Roads become difficult to use during the winter 
months and rainy season. Improvement and maintenance of the existing road network are 
urgent. 
 
4.  With the scattered settlements, many rural communities are still cut off from the road 
network and depend on animal and head-load transport. The main routes consist of the east-
west highway (EWH) connecting Thimphu-Trashigang and 4 north-south highways following 
major river valleys. The network connects all districts, but still some areas can be reached only 
by horse, yak, or ox. More than 30% of blocks are not connected to feeder roads, and another 
30% are only partially connected to feeder roads. In this situation, farmers remain dependent on 
subsistence agriculture, with no access to markets, education, and health care services. There 
is a need to expand the existing network to promote economic growth that will reach the rural 
poor. 
 
5.  The Government's Ninth Five-Year Plan (9FYP: 2002–2007) was prepared based on the 
needs  of  local  governments.  Improving  the  quality  of  life  of  the  rural  population  through 
improved access, reducing dependence on Indian highways for transport to various places in 
the country, and more reliable and safe road transport are the transport sector goals of the Plan. 
DOR's main strategies under the 9FYP are to (i) shorthen, realign, widen, and improve selected 
NHs  to  reduce  transport  cost  and  travel  time,  and  to  enhance  safety;  (ii)  construct  new 
connections and improve access of rural areas to the main network; and (iii) enhance private 
sector participation in road construction and maintenance activities. ADB's country strategy for 
Bhutan  is  consistent  with  the  9FYP,  and  will  continue  to  place  high  priority  on  rural 
development, subregional cooperation, and private sector development.

2 
6.  ADB involvement in the transport sector in Bhutan started in 1983 through its loan and 
TA program, which has resulted in the rehabilitation and improvement of significant sections of 
the main arterial road network, capacity building for institutions, and policy reforms in the sector. 
The development impact of the previous projects has been significant, with a visibly enhanced 
degree of commercial and agricultural development in the project areas. 
 
7.  ADB has provided significant advisory assistance, particularly within PPD and DOR, in 
procurement,  construction  management,  regulatory  framework,  road  network  planning, 
pavement management, and maintenance programming. The latest ADB-financed TA (footnote 
2) has encouraged planning and institutional strengthening in the transport sector.2 It assisted 
the Government in preparing a road master plan, covering 2007-2027 (10FYP-13FYP), which is 
well accepted by external financing agencies. The approach is to use generalized information to 
determine a ranking based on relative benefits and costs, and so establish a pipeline of possible 
projects for implementation in the next 20 years under various levels of funding scenarios. It 
also  provides  recommendations  to  improve  road  policy  and  a  management  system  that 
facilitates efficient budget allocations for road development and maintenance.  
 
8.  The TA also reviewed the issue of sustainable road maintenance. It found that due to 
very low traffic volume resulting from a very low population, the current revenue from road user 
charge, in the form of vehicle registration fees, is far below the required funds for maintenance. 
The draft Road Act, prepared under the TA,3 provides for the creation of one or more road funds 
at national or local level as well as the setting procedures and regulations regarding payments 
and fees. Attention will be given to increasing revenues, particularly with respect to charges on 
fuel and heavy vehicles. However, increases in fuel price will have to consider the price in the 
adjacent countries to prevent smuggling. Given the very low traffic volume, there will be little 
scope for introducing tolls or a build-operate-transfer scheme in Bhutan. The TA therefore 
suggests gradually introducing road user charges, earmarking of road user revenues, and 
eventually establishing a road fund at a later stage. The proposal will need further analysis as 
the level of charges should not reduce the economic benefits resulting from the improved roads 
and the costs of revenue collection and fund administration should not be excessive compared 
with the expected incremental revenue.  
 
9.  The Government appreciates that road sector performance can be improved through 
private sector participation. More road works should be contracted out to the private sector 
rather  than  executed  by  DOR.  In  recent  years,  DOR  has  been  moving  in  this  direction. 
Corporatization of the Mechanical Division is being proposed. However, awarding some works 
to the private sector only will not lead to achieving the vision of privatization. DOR should 
eventually  act  as  a  facilitator,  supervisor,  and  certifier  of  road  works.  On  the  other  hand, 
development of a local consulting and contracting industry is still a pressing need. The industry 
is weak in human resources and lacks access to financing and equipment. There is a need to 
develop a systematic privatization strategy. Such strategy should include a careful analysis of 
the present situation and a proposal on available options for phased privatization. 
 
10.  To facilitate the positive reform of the road sector institutions, there is a need to prepare 
a road map to guide the Government, ADB, and other development partners in the sector in 
Bhutan in the next 5 - 10 years. The Government and ADB agreed that if the objectives of the 
road map are to be achieved, a time-bound realistic and achievable medium-term action plan 
must be prepared.

11.  Together with the involvement of other external agencies, ADB's interventions have 
resulted in the rehabilitation and improvement of significant sections of the main highways. As 
the EWH is of strategic importance to Bhutan, providing the only link through the east, central, 
and western regions of the country without traveling via India, continued attention remains 
essential. Equally important, it is necessary to develop a road network for rural development to 
ensure that social and economic benefits from the main network improvements are maximized 
and that benefits extend to the rural population. Poverty reduction through economic growth and 
improved access for the poor is the theme of ADB's interventions in the transport sector.  
 
12.  The Government and ADB also recognize that, as a landlocked country, Bhutan will 
benefit from regional links and cooperation with adjacent countries that can provide access to 
markets  abroad.  Bhutan  is  participating  in  dialogues  on  multimodal  transport  and 
communication  through  the  ADB-assisted  South  Asia  Subregional  Economic  Cooperation 
(SASEC), comprising Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, and Nepal. A transport sector initiative was 
undertaken  in  October  2001,  and  a  sector  analysis  was  completed.  The  sector  analysis 
identified the current problems facing the subregional transit and transportation systems are 
largely  due  to  institutional  problems.  A  subsequent  TA,  Subregional  Corridor  Operational 
Efficiency Study, will soon start to assess the operational efficiency of selected subregional 
corridors.  On  the  Bhutan  side,  the  indicative  road-based  subregional  corridor  is  Thimphu-
Phuentsholing, and ADB is providing a TA for preparing the industrial estate and dry port 
development  project  in  Phuentsholing.4  Improvement  of  Thimphu-Phuentsholing  is  included 
under  the 9FYP  with  committed  financing from  the  Government  of  India.  To enhance  the 
development objectives of the subregional cooperation, other links to India, including Trongsa-
Gelephu, need to be improved. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
13.  Efficient  transport  and  improved  access  in  particular  are  two  keys  to  economic 
development leading to poverty reduction. Investment in roads is part of a continuing program to 
support the development of an integrated and balanced road network in the country. The TA will 
help  the  Government  improve  transport  efficiency  by  preparing  a  project  that  aims  to  (i) 
strengthen  the  road  sector  institutions,  (ii)  promote  domestic  and  international  trade  by 
improving strategic road networks, and (iii) improve the quality of life of rural communities by 
providing access roads. 
 
14.  The output will consist of the (i) formulation of a midterm road sector development 
framework, recommending steps for achieving the sector objectives; and (ii) preparation of a 
road investment component that is economically viable, technically feasible, and socially and 
environmentally responsible.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
1.  Sector Development Component 
 
15.  The TA will (i) review related Government policy documents, ADB's and other external 
agencies' sector strategy and program, and other relevant studies; (ii) review and analyze

sector performance, key problems, opportunities for development, needs, and development 
challenges; (iii) propose strategies, including financing strategies, to resolve key problems; and 
(iv) prepare a pragmatic and achievable medium-term action plan to implement the strategies. 
The TA will also assist in the initial implementation of the action plan and prepare a privatization 
strategy. Stakeholder workshops will be conducted as necessary to ensure participation and 
promote a sense of ownership of the strategies. 
 
2.  Investment Component 
 
16.  The  TA  will  review  and  update  the  feasibility  study  of  the  EWH  of  Simtokha  - 
Wangduephodrang (64 km), and the north-south highway of Trongsa–Gelephu (244 km).5 It is 
proposed  that  the  roads  be  strengthened,  upgraded,  and  widened  as  appropriate  to 
accommodate the projected traffic. Baseline data will be updated for the current situation, 
analysis and assessment will be revisited in accordance with the latest ADB requirements, 
guidelines, and handbooks for project preparation.  
 
17.  A feasibility study will be carried out for about 130.5 km new FRs. These FRs will 
provide initial connections to remote and poor villages that are otherwise isolated from the 
economic mainstream. The roads that are proposed and prioritized under the 10FYP road 
master plan cover the following districts:  
 
Dagana  :  Drukyegang – Lajab (35 km) 
Tsirang  :  Burichu – Patale (8 km) and Dunglegang – Katike (10 km) 
Pemagatshel  :  Nangkhor – Gamung (10 km) 
Trashigang  :  Zugpola – Kurichilo (15 km) 
Chhukha  :  Mirchim – Bongo – Getana (52.5 km)  
 
18.  The consultant will (i) identify the existing condition of the roads; (ii) forecast traffic flows 
for 20 years; and (iii) identify optimum improvement and construction strategies, taking into 
account the adoption of DOR's environment–friendly road construction approach. Economic 
evaluation will be carried out following ADB's Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects, 
taking into account the extreme conditions of Bhutan and its low traffic volumes. Consideration 
will be given not only to savings from transport cost reduction, but also overall net benefits in 
providing access to market, health, education, and other essential services. 
 
19.  Environmental  assessment  will  be  conducted  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  and  the 
Government’s guidelines and procedures. Social analysis will be carried out in accordance with 
ADB's Guidelines for the Incorporation of Social Dimensions in ADB Operations. The summary 
initial poverty and social analysis is in Appendix 1. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
20.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $625,000 equivalent, comprising $432,000 in 
foreign  exchange  and  $193,000  equivalent  in  local  currency.  ADB  will  provide  $500,000 
equivalent,  covering  the  entire  foreign  exchange  cost  and  $68,000  equivalent  of  the  local 
currency cost, on a grant basis from the Japan Special Fund, funded by the Government of 
Japan. The Government of Bhutan will finance the remaining $125,000 equivalent in local

The Government has been advised that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance the

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
21.  MOC will be the Executing Agency for the TA. The Implementing Agency will be DOR. 
Under the existing project management unit for ADB-financed projects within DOR, an assistant 
project  manager  will  be  responsible  for  day-to-day  implementation  of  the  TA,  including 
coordinating with concerned line ministries, agencies, and external funding agencies. Close 
coordination and extensive consultation with PPD will be necessary in preparing the medium-
term sector road map. The Government has assured the Mission that all required counterpart 
staff,  office  space,  furniture,  equipment,  support  facilities  for  technical  surveys  and 
investigations and for laboratory services, maps, reports, and other support services, will be 
made available to the consultants in a timely manner. 
 
22.  The TA will be implemented over 6 months, beginning around November 2003 and 
ending in April 2004. A multidisciplinary team of consultants will provide about 17 person-
months of international and 14 person-months of domestic inputs. The consultants will have 
expertise in (i) institutional and private sector development, (ii) transport economics, (iii) road 
engineering, (iv) environment, and (v) social development. All consultants will be selected and 
recruited through a firm using the quality- and cost-based selection method, in accordance with 
ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB for 
engaging  domestic  consultants.  Simplified  technical  proposals  will  be  requested  from  the 
shortlisted consultants. Terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 3. 
 
23.  The consultants will submit an inception report no later than 3 weeks after commencing 
their services, focusing on the work program and feeder roads selection. An interim report will 
be submitted 3 months after TA inception, and a draft final report will be submitted 5 months 
after their services begin. A tripartite meeting of the Government, consultants, and ADB to be 
held in Thimphu and chaired by DOR will review the draft final report. Within 3 weeks after the 
meeting, the consultants will submit a final report, in a format acceptable to ADB, incorporating 
all comments received on the draft final report from the Government and ADB. A stakeholders 
workshop  will  be  conducted  on  the  road  sector  development  framework  and  privatization 
strategy. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
24.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bhutan for preparing the Road Network Expansion Project, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in Bhutan: 
The national highways improvement component will support pro-poor economic growth by improving 
transport efficiency – reducing travel time and transport cost – that will support the domestic trade 
and cross-border transport, which will generate increases in employment especially for the poor.  
 
The feeder roads construction component will be targeted to districts/blocks with a high incidence of 
poverty, providing the isolated communities with the initial connection for reasonable access to 
markets, schools, and health centers. The construction will be implemented using environment-
friendly construction methods, which are labor extensive, and will provide employment opportunities 
to local communities. It will reduce poverty by increasing economic efficiency through lower costs 
and prices and enhanced social and economic opportunities.  Although the Project will not be 
focused  on  direct  poverty  reduction,  explicit  attention  to  poverty  issues  and  specific  poverty 
components will be addressed during PPTA stage. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis        Proposed Classification: PI 
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed? 
 
Poverty assessment will be conducted to (i) identify the poverty profile of the population affected by 
the  Project  (including  users);  (ii)  assess  the  relevant  market  structure  and  estimate  the  likely 
distributive impacts of the project; (iii) where appropriate, incorporate the needs of the poor, and 
minimize or compensate for adverse impacts on the poor; (iv) identify more systematic integration of 
the Project with other sectoral interventions (health, education, rural development, etc.) so as to 
strengthen poverty reduction strategies; and (iv) develop low-cost mechanisms for monitoring to 
contribute to the understanding of the links between the Project and poverty reduction. 
 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Stakeholder analysis: 
    
This  TA  is  being  developed  through  extensive  consultation  with  government  and  private 
stakeholders. The roads were selected from the Government Fiscal Year Plan and road master plan, 
which  was  prepared  based  on  roads  identified  by  the  Dzongkhags  and  prioritized  based  on 
community needs. 
 
Participation strategy required: 
    
Public consultations with primary and secondary stakeholders will be conducted throughout the TA.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The consultants will have extensive experience in all elements of the transport sector, 
skills in sound quantitative analysis, and the ability to clearly articulate and present proposals for 
policies and strategies. The team leader must have expertise in transport policy, institutional 
capacity building, private sector development, and road engineering. The team leader will have 
overall responsibility for implementing the technical assistance (TA) and managing the team of 
consultants  with  expertise  in  transport  economics,  road  engineering,  geology,  social 
development, and environment. The TA will require about 17 person-months of international and 
about 14 person-months of domestic consulting services. 
 
2.  The consultants will work closely with the staff of the Ministry of Communications (MOC), 
Policy and Planning Division (PPD), Department of Roads (DOR), district officials, and other 
related ministries/agencies. The consultants will be based in Thimphu and will visit selected 
districts in undertaking their assignment. Workshops will be conducted as required and will 
include all involved stakeholders. The terms of reference (TOR) for the consultants include but 
are not limited to the following:  
 
A.  Road Sector Development Component 
 
3.  Specific tasks related to the road sector development component are as follows: 
(i)  Review MOC's Road Master Plan, the Government's Ninth FYP, ADB previous 
studies  including  TA  3470-BHU:  Roads  Planning  and  Management 
Strengthening Project, other external agencies' sector strategies and programs, 
and relevant studies.  
 
(ii)  Review and analyze sector performance, key problems, and opportunities for 
development, needs and development challenges, and present cause-effect tree 
analysis. Propose strategies to resolve key problems, and prepare a pragmatic 
and  achievable  medium-term  action  plan  (AP)  to  implement  the  strategies, 
including establishing benchmark indicators, monitoring system, and resources 
required to implement the AP. 
 
(iii)  Using Highway Design and Model (HDM-4), identify annual maintenance works 
programs  and  the  associated  costs.  Taking  into  consideration  TA  3470 
recommendations,  propose  options  for  introducing  road  user  charges, 
earmarking road user revenues, and eventually establishing a road maintenance 
fund in a phased manner. Propose the increase of charges and revenues at such 
a level that the economic benefits of the improved roads could be optimized. 
Options  should  be  explored,  taking  into  consideration  the  associated 
administration costs for implementing each option. 
 
(iv)  Review the present situation on private sector participation in the local road 
contracting  industry.  Develop  a  systematic  privatization  strategy  that  will 
eventually have DOR act as a facilitator, supervisor, and certifier of road works, 
with  less  involvement  in  implementation.  Analyze  options  and  opportunities 
available for developing private industries in road construction and management.  
 
(v)  Conduct a stakeholder workshop, including external funding agencies involved in 
the road sector, to discuss the AP and finalize it accordingly.

(vi)  Help  the  Government  initially  implement  the  AP.  Develop  TOR  and  cost 
estimates of further technical assistance required in implementing the AP. 
 
B.  Road Investment Component 
 
4.  The investment component covers national highways of Simtokha - Wangduephodrang 
(64 km) and Trongsa – Gelephu (244 km), and the following new FRs totaling about 130.5 km:  
 
Dagana district  :  Drukyegang – Lajab (35 km) 
Tsirang district   :  Burichu – Patale (8 km) and Dunglegang – Katike (10 km) 
Pemagatshel district  :  Nangkhor – Gamung (10 km) 
Trashigang district  :  Zugpola – Kurichilo (15 km) 
Chhukha district  :  Mirchim – Bongo – Getana (52.5 km)  
 
5.  The consultant will review all available reports and data –including traffic surveys and 
beneficiaries–  related  to  the  subject  roads.  The  consultant  will  also  review  (i)  an  earlier 
feasibility study on the project NHs (TA 3107-BHU: Road Transport Network Development 
Project),  as  regards  technical,  economic,  environmental,  and  social  aspects;  and  (ii)  a 
preliminary study for the project FRs during the preparation of the Road Master Plan under the 
ADB-funded TA 3470-BHU: Road Planning and Management Strengthening Project, which 
should also be reviewed.  
 
6.  The consultants’ tasks for the specific studies under the road investment component are 
as follows. 
 
1.  Engineering Study 
 
(i)  Review  available  engineering  data  and  study  on  the  project  roads.  Survey 
conditions  of  the  roads  identified  for  the  Project,  evaluate  their  pavement 
strength, determine residual life, and divide the roads into homogenous sections. 
 
(ii)  Review existing traffic data; carry out necessary traffic counts, origin-destination, 
and axle load surveys; and forecast traffic for each road section. 
 
(iii)  Survey typical slope stability problems on the road network, analyze their cause, 
and develop recommendations for mitigating them. 
 
(iv)  For the new FRs, conduct geological studies and propose alignment, avoiding 
landslide–prone areas. 
 
(v)  Propose a required level of improvement for each road section, and estimate the 
required costs of civil works including foreign exchange and local components, 
separately identifying taxes and customs duties. 
 
(vi)  Prepare  a  summary  of  technical  approach  and  design  standard,  taking  into 
account the environment-friendly road construction method applied in the Road 
Access Project.  
(vii)  Propose appropriate contract packages, indicate for each package the suitable 
procurement method, and prepare draft standard bid documents accordingly. 
 
(viii)  Prepare the proposed project implementation schedule.

(ix)  In  consultation  with  other  specialists,  develop  draft  TOR  for  consultants  for 
detailed  engineering  design  and  construction  supervision,  and  estimate  the 
required resources (person-months and costs). 
2.  Economic Analysis and Poverty Assessment 
 
(i)  Review available data and economic analysis of the project roads. Obtain the 
most  recent  available  traffic,  road  condition  data,  required  construction/ 
improvement, and estimated civil works and maintenance. 
 
(ii)  Determine  financial  and  economic  vehicle  operating  costs  for  representative 
vehicle types. 
 
(iii)  Prepare economic evaluation of the proposed improvements following ADB's 
Guidelines  for  the  Economic  Analysis  of  Projects,  taking  into  account  the 
reduction  of  travel  time  and  transport  costs  in  project  areas,  increase  of 
agricultural production, and other net social benefits resulting from improved 
access.  The  latter  includes  quantified  education  and  health  benefits  (e.g., 
reduced  distance  to  health  and  education  services,  increased  enrollment  of 
students  in  primary  and  junior  high  schools  in  corridors  of  impact,  reduced 
number of sick days and deaths from improved access to health centers).  
 
(iv)  Develop  optimum  road  improvement  strategies  using  HDM-4  for  each  road

(v)  Carry  out  program  optimization,  considering  likely  budget  constraints  in 
developing a recommended program of works to be implemented under the 
proposed project, including least-cost options, economic rates of return, and 
priority rankings. 
 
(vi)  Undertake switching value calculations, and sensitivity analysis for variations in 
key parameters and budget constraints. Undertake risk analysis in accordance 
with ADB's Handbook for Integrating Risk Analysis of Projects. 
 
(vii)  Review the structure of the road transport industry and assess the degree of 
competitiveness in service provision. 
 
(viii)  Conduct poverty impact assessment in accordance with ADB's Handbook for 
Integrating Poverty Impact Assessment in the Economic Analysis of Projects.  
 
(ix)  Conduct socioeconomic and poverty mapping of the affected districts based on 
existing household and income data (including data from recent poverty studies).  
 
(x)  Identify areas of highest unemployment and underemployment, and the income

(xi)  Analyze how limited access to transportation services contributes to poverty in 
the project area of influence.

3.  Social Analysis 
 
(i)  Identify  key  stakeholders'  (poor  and  vulnerable  groups  in  particular)  project-
related interests, likely barriers to their participation in and benefiting from the 
project resources, and suggest possible strategies for addressing their concerns. 
 
(ii)  With participation of all stakeholders, identify all groups at risk with respect to the 
project, and analyze the reasons for their vulnerability, including their exposure to 
risks, as described in ADB’s Handbook for Poverty and Social Analysis. 
 
(iii)  Identify mitigation measures or safety nets that will be needed and the strategy 
for  implementing  them.  Identify  potential  proactive  measures,  in  terms  of 
additional components and design options, which will make it easy for the poor 
and vulnerable to benefit from the project. 
 
(iv)  Design  and  conduct  any  necessary  socioeconomic  surveys  using  household 
questionnaires  and  participatory  approaches.  Prepare  an  overview  of  ethnic 
population characteristics in each road's zone of influence for both mainstream

ethnic groups in the zone of influence and propose mitigation measures. 
 
(v)  If required, prepare an involuntary resettlement and ethnic minority development

Good Practice and ADB's Policy on Indigenous People. 
 
(vi)  Prepare gender analysis and identify project design elements (policy, investment,

(ix)  Identify  institutions  (government  and  nongovernment)  with  a  focus  on

(x)  Incorporate  any  issues  related  to  poverty  and  social  risk  into  the  project 
framework and include possible indicators to be incorporated into the framework 
and project performance monitoring system. 
 
(xi)  Identify  covenants  or  policy  changes  necessary  to  ensure  the  protection  of

4.  Environmental Assessment 
 
(i)  Gather  and  review  all  available  environmental  studies  related  to  the  project 
highways  and  feeder  roads,  and  undertake  a  field  survey  to  produce  a 
comprehensive environmental assessment for the project roads.  
 
(ii)  Prepare an environmental management plan to implement mitigation measures 
for each road section. 
 
(iii)  Prepare  an  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  and  its  summary  in 
accordance  with  ADB's  and  the  Government's  environmental  assessment 
guidelines for highways improvement and FR construction. 
 
(iv)  If the IEE recommends that a full environmental impact assessment (EIA) be 
undertaken, prepare TOR acceptable to ADB and the National Environmental 
Commission.  Conduct  the  EIA  and  prepare  the  report  and  its  summary 
accordingly. 
 
(v)  Assess the capacity of DOR to implement the proposed mitigation measures, 
and  recommend  necessary  training  or  other  form  of  activities  to  strengthen 
DOR’s  capacity  to  deal  with  environmental  problems  related  to  road  sector 
development in general.
